#!/bin/bash

# Enhanced TTS script - DELAYED VERSION - waits for transcript completion
echo "$(date): Enhanced TTS DELAYED hook triggered" >> /tmp/claude_tts_debug.log

# Read JSON input from stdin
input=$(cat)
echo "Input received: $input" >> /tmp/claude_tts_debug.log

# Extract session_id and transcript_path from JSON input
session_id=$(echo "$input" | jq -r '.session_id // empty')
transcript_path=$(echo "$input" | jq -r '.transcript_path // empty')
echo "Session ID: $session_id" >> /tmp/claude_tts_debug.log
echo "Transcript path: $transcript_path" >> /tmp/claude_tts_debug.log

if [[ -n "$transcript_path" && -f "$transcript_path" ]]; then
    echo "File exists and is readable" >> /tmp/claude_tts_debug.log
    
    # Wait for transcript to be fully written by polling for a complete entry
    # We'll wait up to 5 seconds, checking every 0.5 seconds
    max_attempts=10
    attempt=0
    last_response=""
    
    while [[ $attempt -lt $max_attempts ]]; do
        # Get the last few lines and look for the most recent assistant response
        last_lines=$(tail -20 "$transcript_path" 2>/dev/null)
        
        # Look for assistant response with our session ID
        temp_response=$(echo "$last_lines" | tail -r | while read -r line; do
            if [[ -n "$line" ]]; then
                # Check if this is an assistant message with matching session
                role=$(echo "$line" | jq -r '.message.role // empty' 2>/dev/null)
                type=$(echo "$line" | jq -r '.type // empty' 2>/dev/null)
                line_session=$(echo "$line" | jq -r '.sessionId // empty' 2>/dev/null)
                
                if [[ "$role" == "assistant" && "$type" == "assistant" && "$line_session" == "$session_id" ]]; then
                    # Try to extract text content
                    text_content=$(echo "$line" | jq -r '.message.content[]? | select(.type == "text") | .text // empty' 2>/dev/null)
                    
                    if [[ -n "$text_content" && ${#text_content} -gt 20 ]]; then
                        echo "$text_content"
                        exit 0
                    fi
                fi
            fi
        done 2>/dev/null)
        
        if [[ -n "$temp_response" && ${#temp_response} -gt 20 ]]; then
            last_response="$temp_response"
            echo "Found complete response on attempt $((attempt + 1)): ${#last_response} chars" >> /tmp/claude_tts_debug.log
            break
        fi
        
        echo "Attempt $((attempt + 1)): Waiting for complete transcript entry..." >> /tmp/claude_tts_debug.log
        sleep 0.5
        ((attempt++))
    done
    
    if [[ -z "$last_response" ]]; then
        echo "Timeout: Falling back to any available response" >> /tmp/claude_tts_debug.log
        # Fallback: try to get any recent assistant response
        last_response=$(echo "$last_lines" | tail -r | while read -r line; do
            if [[ -n "$line" ]]; then
                role=$(echo "$line" | jq -r '.message.role // empty' 2>/dev/null)
                type=$(echo "$line" | jq -r '.type // empty' 2>/dev/null)
                
                if [[ "$role" == "assistant" && "$type" == "assistant" ]]; then

                    if [[ -n "$text_content" && ${#text_content} -gt 10 ]]; then
                        echo "$text_content"
                        exit 0
                    fi
                fi
            fi
        done 2>/dev/null)
    fi
    
    echo "Final extracted response length: ${#last_response}" >> /tmp/claude_tts_debug.log
    echo "First 150 chars: ${last_response:0:150}..." >> /tmp/claude_tts_debug.log
    
    if [[ -n "$last_response" && ${#last_response} -gt 10 ]]; then
        # Clean up markdown
        clean_text=$(echo "$last_response" | \
            sed 's/\\n/ /g' | \
            sed 's/\*\*\([^*]*\)\*\*/\1/g' | \
            sed 's/`\([^`]*\)`/\1/g' | \
            sed 's/<[^>]*>//g')
        
        echo "Cleaned text length: ${#clean_text}" >> /tmp/claude_tts_debug.log
        
        # Get the last 120 characters which should contain the final sentences
        final_sentence=$(echo "$clean_text" | tail -c 120 | sed 's/^[[:space:]]*//')
        
        # Try to start from a capital letter if available
        if [[ "$final_sentence" =~ [A-Z] ]]; then

        # Speak the final sentence at a slower rate
        if [[ -n "$final_sentence" && ${#final_sentence} -gt 3 ]]; then
            # Use -r flag to set speech rate (words per minute)
            # User prefers 220 WPM for optimal speech
            nohup say -r 220 "$final_sentence" > /dev/null 2>&1 &

That's exactly right! The TTS system is working perfectly - it correctly extracted and spoke the **final sentence** of my response, which was:

The system is designed to speak the **ending portion** of my responses (last ~120 characters), not the beginning. This is exactly what you wanted - to hear the **conclusions, punchlines, and final thoughts** rather than the opening sentences.

content.text: Great idea! Let me modify the script to extract the **last paragraph** instead of just the last characters. This will give you complete final thoughts rather than partial sentences:

input.old_string:
# Get the last 120 characters which should contain the final sentences
        final_sentence=$(echo "$clean_text" | tail -c 120 | sed 's/^[[:space:]]*//')
        
        # Try to start from a capital letter if available
        if [[ "$final_sentence" =~ [A-Z] ]]; then
            better_start=$(echo "$final_sentence" | sed 's/^[^A-Z]*\([A-Z].*\)/\1/')
            if [[ -n "$better_start" && ${#better_start} -gt 10 ]]; then
                final_sentence="$better_start"
            fi
        fi
input.new_string:
# Get the LAST PARAGRAPH by splitting on double newlines and taking the final one
        # Split on paragraph breaks (double newlines) and get the last paragraph
        last_paragraph=$(echo "$clean_text" | sed 's/\\n\\n/\n\n/g' | awk 'BEGIN{RS="\n\n"} END{print}' | sed 's/^[[:space:]]*//' | sed 's/[[:space:]]*$//')
        
        # If the last paragraph is too short or empty, try splitting on single newlines
        if [[ -z "$last_paragraph" || ${#last_paragraph} -lt 20 ]]; then
            last_paragraph=$(echo "$clean_text" | sed 's/\\n/\n/g' | awk 'END{print}' | sed 's/^[[:space:]]*//')
        fi
        
        # If still too short, fall back to last 150 characters
        if [[ -z "$last_paragraph" || ${#last_paragraph} -lt 15 ]]; then
            last_paragraph=$(echo "$clean_text" | tail -c 150 | sed 's/^[[:space:]]*//')
        fi
        
        final_sentence="$last_paragraph"

input.old_string: echo "Final sentence for TTS: $final_sentence" >> /tmp/claude_tts_debug.log
input.new_string: echo "Final paragraph for TTS: $final_sentence" >> /tmp/claude_tts_debug.log

                        echo "$text_content"
                        exit 0
                    fi
                fi
            fi
        done 2>/dev/null)
        
        if [[ -n "$temp_response" && ${#temp_response} -gt 20 ]]; then
            last_response="$temp_response"
            echo "Found complete response on attempt $((attempt + 1)): ${#last_response} chars" >> /tmp/claude_tts_debug.log
            break
        fi
        
        echo "Attempt $((attempt + 1)): Waiting for complete transcript entry..." >> /tmp/claude_tts_debug.log
        sleep 0.5
        ((attempt++))
    done
    
    if [[ -z "$last_response" ]]; then
        echo "Timeout: Falling back to any available response" >> /tmp/claude_tts_debug.log
        # Fallback: try to get any recent assistant response
        last_response=$(echo "$last_lines" | tail -r | while read -r line; do
            if [[ -n "$line" ]]; then
                role=$(echo "$line" | jq -r '.message.role // empty' 2>/dev/null)
                type=$(echo "$line" | jq -r '.type // empty' 2>/dev/null)
                
                if [[ "$role" == "assistant" && "$type" == "assistant" ]]; then
                    text_content=$(echo "$line" | jq -r '.message.content[]? | select(.type == "text") | .text // empty' 2>/dev/null)
                    if [[ -n "$text_content" && ${#text_content} -gt 10 ]]; then
                        echo "$text_content"
                        exit 0
                    fi
                fi
            fi
        done 2>/dev/null)
    fi
    
    echo "Final extracted response length: ${#last_response}" >> /tmp/claude_tts_debug.log
    echo "First 150 chars: ${last_response:0:150}..." >> /tmp/claude_tts_debug.log
    
    if [[ -n "$last_response" && ${#last_response} -gt 10 ]]; then
        # Clean up markdown
        clean_text=$(echo "$last_response" | \
            sed 's/\\n/ /g' | \
            sed 's/\*\*\([^*]*\)\*\*/\1/g' | \
            sed 's/`\([^`]*\)`/\1/g' | \
            sed 's/<[^>]*>//g')
        
        echo "Cleaned text length: ${#clean_text}" >> /tmp/claude_tts_debug.log
        
        # Get the LAST PARAGRAPH by splitting on double newlines and taking the final one
        # Split on paragraph breaks (double newlines) and get the last paragraph
        last_paragraph=$(echo "$clean_text" | sed 's/\\n\\n/\n\n/g' | awk 'BEGIN{RS="\n\n"} END{print}' | sed 's/^[[:space:]]*//' | sed 's/[[:space:]]*$//')
        
        # If the last paragraph is too short or empty, try splitting on single newlines
        if [[ -z "$last_paragraph" || ${#last_paragraph} -lt 20 ]]; then
            last_paragraph=$(echo "$clean_text" | sed 's/\\n/\n/g' | awk 'END{print}' | sed 's/^[[:space:]]*//')
        fi
        
        # If still too short, fall back to last 150 characters
        if [[ -z "$last_paragraph" || ${#last_paragraph} -lt 15 ]]; then
            last_paragraph=$(echo "$clean_text" | tail -c 150 | sed 's/^[[:space:]]*//')
        fi
        
        final_sentence="$last_paragraph"
        
        echo "Final sentence for TTS: $final_sentence" >> /tmp/claude_tts_debug.log
        
        # Speak the final sentence at a slower rate
        if [[ -n "$final_sentence" && ${#final_sentence} -gt 3 ]]; then
            # Use -r flag to set speech rate (words per minute)
            # User prefers 220 WPM for optimal speech
            nohup say -r 220 "$final_sentence" > /dev/null 2>&1 &
            echo "TTS executed successfully with delay at 220 WPM" >> /tmp/claude_tts_debug.log
        else
            nohup say -r 220 "Claude response complete" > /dev/null 2>&1 &
            echo "Fallback TTS executed - final sentence too short" >> /tmp/claude_tts_debug.log
        fi
    else
        # Fallback message
        nohup say -r 220 "Claude response complete" > /dev/null 2>&1 &
        echo "Fallback TTS executed - no response found after delay" >> /tmp/claude_tts_debug.log
    fi
else
    # Fallback if no transcript available
    nohup say -r 220 "Claude response complete" > /dev/null 2>&1 &
    echo "Fallback TTS executed - no transcript available" >> /tmp/claude_tts_debug.log
fi

toolUseResult.originalFile:
#!/bin/bash

# Enhanced TTS script - Speaks the last paragraph of Claude responses
echo "$(date): Enhanced TTS hook triggered" >> /tmp/claude_tts_debug.log

# Read JSON input from stdin
input=$(cat)
echo "Input received: $input" >> /tmp/claude_tts_debug.log

# Extract session_id and transcript_path from JSON input
session_id=$(echo "$input" | jq -r '.session_id // empty')
transcript_path=$(echo "$input" | jq -r '.transcript_path // empty')
echo "Session ID: $session_id" >> /tmp/claude_tts_debug.log
echo "Transcript path: $transcript_path" >> /tmp/claude_tts_debug.log

if [[ -n "$transcript_path" && -f "$transcript_path" ]]; then
    echo "File exists and is readable" >> /tmp/claude_tts_debug.log
    
    # Wait for transcript to be fully written by polling for a complete entry
    # We'll wait up to 5 seconds, checking every 0.5 seconds
    max_attempts=10
    attempt=0
    last_response=""
    
    while [[ $attempt -lt $max_attempts ]]; do
        # Get the last few lines and look for the most recent assistant response
        last_lines=$(tail -20 "$transcript_path" 2>/dev/null)
        
        # Look for assistant response with our session ID
        temp_response=$(echo "$last_lines" | tail -r | while read -r line; do
            if [[ -n "$line" ]]; then
                # Check if this is an assistant message with matching session
                role=$(echo "$line" | jq -r '.message.role // empty' 2>/dev/null)
                type=$(echo "$line" | jq -r '.type // empty' 2>/dev/null)
                line_session=$(echo "$line" | jq -r '.sessionId // empty' 2>/dev/null)
                
                if [[ "$role" == "assistant" && "$type" == "assistant" && "$line_session" == "$session_id" ]]; then
                    # Try to extract text content
                    text_content=$(echo "$line" | jq -r '.message.content[]? | select(.type == "text") | .text // empty' 2>/dev/null)
                    
                    if [[ -n "$text_content" && ${#text_content} -gt 20 ]]; then
                        echo "$text_content"
                        exit 0
                    fi
                fi
            fi
        done 2>/dev/null)
        
        if [[ -n "$temp_response" && ${#temp_response} -gt 20 ]]; then
            last_response="$temp_response"
            echo "Found complete response on attempt $((attempt + 1)): ${#last_response} chars" >> /tmp/claude_tts_debug.log
            break
        fi
        
        echo "Attempt $((attempt + 1)): Waiting for complete transcript entry..." >> /tmp/claude_tts_debug.log
        sleep 0.5
        ((attempt++))
    done
    
    if [[ -z "$last_response" ]]; then
        echo "Timeout: Falling back to any available response" >> /tmp/claude_tts_debug.log
        # Fallback: try to get any recent assistant response
        last_response=$(echo "$last_lines" | tail -r | while read -r line; do
            if [[ -n "$line" ]]; then
                role=$(echo "$line" | jq -r '.message.role // empty' 2>/dev/null)
                type=$(echo "$line" | jq -r '.type // empty' 2>/dev/null)
                
                if [[ "$role" == "assistant" && "$type" == "assistant" ]]; then
                    text_content=$(echo "$line" | jq -r '.message.content[]? | select(.type == "text") | .text // empty' 2>/dev/null)
                    if [[ -n "$text_content" && ${#text_content} -gt 10 ]]; then
                        echo "$text_content"
                        exit 0
                    fi
                fi
            fi
        done 2>/dev/null)
    fi
    
    echo "Final extracted response length: ${#last_response}" >> /tmp/claude_tts_debug.log
    echo "First 150 chars: ${last_response:0:150}..." >> /tmp/claude_tts_debug.log
    
    if [[ -n "$last_response" && ${#last_response} -gt 10 ]]; then
        # Clean up markdown
        clean_text=$(echo "$last_response" | \
            sed 's/\\n/ /g' | \
            sed 's/\*\*\([^*]*\)\*\*/\1/g' | \
            sed 's/`\([^`]*\)`/\1/g' | \
            sed 's/<[^>]*>//g')
        
        echo "Cleaned text length: ${#clean_text}" >> /tmp/claude_tts_debug.log
        
        # Get the LAST PARAGRAPH by splitting on double newlines and taking the final one
        # Split on paragraph breaks (double newlines) and get the last paragraph
        last_paragraph=$(echo "$clean_text" | sed 's/\\n\\n/\n\n/g' | awk 'BEGIN{RS="\n\n"} END{print}' | sed 's/^[[:space:]]*//' | sed 's/[[:space:]]*$//')
        
        # If the last paragraph is too short or empty, try splitting on single newlines
        if [[ -z "$last_paragraph" || ${#last_paragraph} -lt 20 ]]; then
            last_paragraph=$(echo "$clean_text" | sed 's/\\n/\n/g' | awk 'END{print}' | sed 's/^[[:space:]]*//')
        fi
        
        # If still too short, fall back to last 150 characters
        if [[ -z "$last_paragraph" || ${#last_paragraph} -lt 15 ]]; then
            last_paragraph=$(echo "$clean_text" | tail -c 150 | sed 's/^[[:space:]]*//')
        fi
        
        final_sentence="$last_paragraph"
        
        echo "Final paragraph for TTS: $final_sentence" >> /tmp/claude_tts_debug.log
        
        # Speak the final sentence at a slower rate
        if [[ -n "$final_sentence" && ${#final_sentence} -gt 3 ]]; then
            # Use -r flag to set speech rate (words per minute)
            # User prefers 220 WPM for optimal speech
            nohup say -r 220 "$final_sentence" > /dev/null 2>&1 &
            echo "TTS executed successfully at 220 WPM" >> /tmp/claude_tts_debug.log
        else
            nohup say -r 220 "Claude response complete" > /dev/null 2>&1 &
            echo "Fallback TTS executed - final sentence too short" >> /tmp/claude_tts_debug.log
        fi
    else
        # Fallback message
        nohup say -r 220 "Claude response complete" > /dev/null 2>&1 &
        echo "Fallback TTS executed - no response found after delay" >> /tmp/claude_tts_debug.log
    fi
else
    # Fallback if no transcript available
    nohup say -r 220 "Claude response complete" > /dev/null 2>&1 &
    echo "Fallback TTS executed - no transcript available" >> /tmp/claude_tts_debug.log
fi

message.content:
This session is being continued from a previous conversation that ran out of context. The conversation is summarized below:
Analysis:
Let me chronologically analyze this conversation to capture all technical details, user requests, and development decisions:

1. **Initial Request**: User wanted to continue previous work, which revealed they were working on a Claude Code audio notification hook system.

2. **System Discovery**: Found existing TTS configuration in ~/.claude/settings.json with Glass.aiff sound and simple_tts.sh script.

3. **Core Problem Identification**: The TTS system was only saying "Claude response complete" instead of speaking the actual response content.

4. **Technical Investigation**: Discovered Claude Code hooks receive JSON with transcript_path, session_id, etc. The challenge was extracting Claude's response text from JSONL transcript files.

5. **Multiple Iteration Cycles**: Went through several script versions (v1, v2, v3, final, simple, delayed) to solve various issues:
   - Transcript parsing problems
   - Sentence extraction logic
   - Timing issues where transcript wasn't fully written when hook executed
   - Speech rate adjustments (150 â†’ 260 â†’ 220 WPM)
   - Character-based vs paragraph-based extraction

6. **Key Breakthrough**: Discovered the fundamental timing issue - Stop hooks fire before transcript is fully written, requiring a polling/delay mechanism.

7. **Final Implementation**: Created a working system that extracts the last paragraph of Claude responses and speaks them at 220 WPM.

8. **Cleanup Phase**: Removed all intermediate test files and added log rotation for maintenance.

The user provided specific feedback throughout, particularly about speech rates and wanting to hear last sentences/paragraphs rather than first sentences.

Summary:
1. Primary Request and Intent:
   The user wanted to continue work on a Claude Code audio notification system that would not only play a sound when Claude finishes responding but also speak the last sentences of Claude's responses aloud using text-to-speech. The specific intent was to hear concluding thoughts, punchlines of jokes, and final sentences rather than opening sentences or generic completion messages.

2. Key Technical Concepts:
   - Claude Code Stop hooks and hook architecture
   - JSONL transcript file format and structure
   - macOS `say` command with speech rate control (-r flag)
   - JSON parsing with `jq` for transcript data extraction
   - Bash scripting with polling mechanisms and timeouts
   - Text preprocessing for TTS (markdown removal, character limits)
   - Paragraph-based vs character-based text extraction
   - Timing issues between hook execution and transcript writing
   - Process management with `nohup` for background TTS execution

3. Files and Code Sections:
   - `/Users/terryli/.claude/settings.json`
     - Core configuration file defining Stop hook with Glass.aiff sound and simple_tts.sh
     - Contains hook array with command type entries and timeout values
     ```json
     {
       "model": "sonnet",
       "hooks": {
         "Stop": [
           {
             "hooks": [
               {
                 "type": "command",
                 "command": "afplay /System/Library/Sounds/Glass.aiff",
                 "timeout": 5000
               },
               {
                 "type": "command", 
                 "command": "/Users/terryli/.claude/simple_tts.sh",
                 "timeout": 10000
               }
             ]
           }
         ]
       }
     }
     ```

   - `/Users/terryli/.claude/simple_tts.sh` (177 bytes)
     - Entry point script that passes JSON input to enhanced TTS script
     - Handles logging and delegates to main TTS logic
     ```bash
     #!/bin/bash
     echo "$(date): Simple TTS hook triggered" >> /tmp/claude_tts_debug.log
     
     # Pass the JSON input to the enhanced TTS script
     cat | /Users/terryli/.claude/enhanced_tts.sh
     ```

   - `/Users/terryli/.claude/enhanced_tts.sh` (6.1KB)
     - Main TTS logic with polling mechanism to wait for transcript completion
     - Extracts last paragraph from Claude responses and speaks at 220 WPM
     - Includes automatic log rotation when debug log exceeds 50KB
     - Key sections include transcript polling, paragraph extraction, and TTS execution

   - `/tmp/claude_tts_debug.log`
     - Debug logging file tracking hook execution, response extraction, and TTS status
     - Grew to 44KB with 539 lines during development
     - Now includes automatic rotation when exceeding 50KB

   - Various transcript files in `~/.claude/projects/` (JSONL format)
     - Contains conversation data in JSON Lines format
     - Each line represents a message with role, content, timestamps, session IDs
     - Critical for extracting Claude's response text for TTS

4. Errors and fixes:
   - **Timing Issue**: Stop hook executed before transcript was fully written, causing extraction of incomplete responses (5 characters vs full responses)
     - **Fix**: Implemented polling mechanism with 10 attempts, 0.5-second delays, session ID matching
     - **User feedback**: Confirmed they were only hearing partial responses, not complete final sentences

   - **Sentence Splitting Problems**: Complex regex patterns for sentence extraction failed with syntax errors involving semicolons in character classes
     - **Fix**: Simplified to character-based approach, then evolved to paragraph-based extraction
     - **User feedback**: Requested hearing last sentences instead of first sentences, then requested paragraph-based rather than character-based extraction

   - **Speech Rate Issues**: Initial 150 WPM was too slow, 260 WPM was too fast
     - **Fix**: Settled on 220 WPM based on user feedback
     - **User feedback**: "rate at 260 is preferred" then "rate at 220 is preferred"

   - **Response Content Extraction**: Initially extracted wrong parts of responses (setup instead of punchlines for jokes)
     - **Fix**: Improved paragraph extraction logic with multiple fallback strategies
     - **User feedback**: "I heard 'Why don't skeletons fight each other?' but wanted 'They don't have the guts!'"

5. Problem Solving:
   - **Root Cause Analysis**: Determined Claude Code transcript timing was the fundamental issue, not script logic
   - **Polling Strategy**: Implemented robust polling with session ID matching and graceful fallbacks
   - **Text Processing Pipeline**: Developed markdown cleanup â†’ paragraph extraction â†’ TTS execution workflow
   - **Maintenance Automation**: Added log rotation to prevent debug file bloat
   - **Performance Optimization**: Streamlined from multiple test scripts to clean production system

    - "continue where I left off"
    - "I want to continue my effort. font. With love With love It will not only say stuff and ring a sound, but will say the last sentences as well."
    - "I'm only hearing the glass sound only"
    - "tell me a joke" (multiple instances)
    - "I heard why don't skeletons fight each other. Instead of that they don't have the guts."
    - "It's reading out aloud the first sentences of the response, such as 'I've just heard "Perfect! The fix worked. Now it shows:"'"

    - "Is there anywhere through looking up Claude Code documentation that we can know where the response is safely stored so that we can go look at that."
    - "yes" (regarding implementing delay-based workaround)
    - "I finally hear 'This should solve the timing issue and allow you to hear the complete final sentences and punchlines.' But I love to modify and hear the last paragraph at a slower speech rate."
    - "rate at 260 is preferred."
    - "rate at 220 is preferred."

    - "I heard 'Perfect! The fix worked. Now it shows:'"
    - "I finally hear 'This should solve the timing issue and allow you to hear the complete final sentences and punchlines.'"
    - "Identify not by number of characters by paragraph but by paragraph."
    - "Now we know what's working now and remove all the intermediary and test documentations and test script and leave what's working now."
    - "Is there any way, any additional things that we need to be aware of and need to do clean-up and housekeeping?"
    - "Your task is to create a detailed summary..."

7. Pending Tasks:
   - No pending tasks - the system is complete and production-ready

8. Current Work:
   The most recent work involved final housekeeping and cleanup of the completed TTS system. Specifically:
   - Removed all intermediate test scripts (enhanced_tts.sh, enhanced_tts_v2.sh, enhanced_tts_v3.sh, etc.)
   - Renamed enhanced_tts_delayed.sh to enhanced_tts.sh for cleaner naming
   - Added automatic log rotation to prevent debug log bloat (rotates when >50KB)
   - Verified proper file permissions (755) on all scripts
   - Confirmed no temporary files or cleanup items remaining

   The user asked: "Is there any way, any additional things that we need to be aware of and need to do clean-up and housekeeping?" and I responded by implementing log rotation and confirming the system is production-ready with automatic maintenance.

9. Optional Next Step:
   No next steps - the project is complete. The user's TTS system is now fully functional, automatically maintained, and production-ready. The system successfully:
   - Plays Glass.aiff sound on response completion
   - Waits for transcript completion (solving timing issues)  
   - Extracts and speaks the last paragraph of Claude responses
   - Operates at the user's preferred 220 WPM speech rate
   - Includes automatic log rotation for maintenance
